content.description:
Ascend a snow and ice gully to a narrow chimney full of ice. Climb up the chimney using stemming moves when possible to a verglassed slab. One or two moves on the slab will land you onto a ledge. Easy snow and ice will get you to the top. Interesting but scary climb. In really fat conditions it would be easier to protect and climb but that only happens rarely.

From Chock it Up drop down to the base of a buttress. Follow the base of the cliff band past two gullies and a large tall rock wall that leads up into a very large gully. Move up and around a detached buttress to find the chimney behind.
A rack of ice screws. Tree anchor on top.

A fun warm up or solo. You are climbing in a tight slot so be careful where you belay to avoid ice fall.  The two refrigerator sized chock stones make for an interesting experience.

Found up and right of It's Never Enough. Follow a snow gulley up into a slot canyon that opens up into a bowl above the chockstones.
A rack of screws. Tree anchor.

Beauty mixed line with a lot of variety and position to make it a classic. Start up a steep curtain that leads to a low angle ramp to an free hanging curtain. Someday that curtain may touch down making this route go completely on ice but it likely only forms on rare occasions. Belay on bolts left of the curtain then start up the mixed pitch. Semi decent rock but very well protected makes this a good pitch of dry tooling. Belay on bolts below the final 120 feet of ice. Pitch 3 goes up the obvious gully of ice. Depending on the time of year it could be a scratchy, chimney/stemming affair or a steep narrow runnel of ice. Belay off one the large Spruce trees at the top.
History: The first ascent was done at A0. FFA of pitch 2 was done by Max Fisher and Craig Norris but they elected to rap rather than climb the last pitch. The first complete and free send was by Luc Gallant in 2019. 

Easy to find about halfway between the White Fang area and Geezer Falls. Big obvious gully on a broad wall that faces west. 
A rack of screws and draws.

Easy climbing up slabby ice falls in the sun. A great climb to warm up on and start your day. The climb splits into two routes about midway up. Slightly harder on the right.

From the campsite head up and left. Look for a drainage and waterfall.
A rack of screws if you don't want to solo it.

Fun climb with a little bit of everything. Crux protects very well.  
 Pitch 1: Climb a cool ramp up to a couple of ice daggers (crux). Clip a bolt then climb ice rock to get to a ledge where you will find a tree anchor. 
 Pitch 2: Several options here; up and left, middle or right - all good.

Found just right of Geezer Falls, very hard to miss from there.
A rack of screws, stubbies for the ramp if it isn't fat. 3 bolts, tree anchors

Pitch 1: Climb thin ice to a ledge. 
 Pitch 2: Follow a left trending ramp to the top.

This route is not really in the Geezer area but it is on the same side of the brook. You will find it about 250 yards downstream from Walton Glen falls or directly opposite the Sea Monster Wall. Locate a barely visible line of ice on the north side of the brook.
A rack of screws. Tree anchor.

climbs.name: Reluctant Arborist
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Annette Boerlage and Amir Zuccolo

content.description:
A fun little climb that is harder than it looks. Very cool finish.

Found about 20 feet up from Thick or Thin.  A short but steep start leads to a slab and another steep headwall.
A rack of screws. Tree anchor.

climbs.name: Thick or Thin
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Pierre Arsenault and Mike Delaney

content.description:
A well protected, pleasant mixed climb. Fun moves over rock and thin ice lead to a thick ice flow that steepens near the top. A good warm up for White Fang.

Found about 100 feet above the base of White Fang. Look for some bolts below ice up high.
A rack of screws. 3 bolts protect the rock or thin ice start. Tree anchor.

Fantastic climb on a brilliant column of ice. Steep, sustained, technical climbing with difficult foot placements for the first 2/3 then eases off to WI3. Varies in thickness from year to year for no apparent reason.

Just right of Chimney Fire. Impossible to miss.
A full rack of screws. Tree anchor at the top.

This area is found about a hundred yards downstream from Walton Glen Falls. Locate a flat area on the north side of the brook that is commonly used as a campsite. From here walk up and left to a brook which will lead you to the first climb on the left - Geezer Falls.  All climbs in this area are south facing (except Chock it Up) and receive a lot of afternoon sun.
